page.title: 06Hatfield Broad Oak Surveyed
page.content: One of the most interesting things about the central part of the village near the church is the knowledge that it has altered very little during the past four hundred years since the dissolution of the monastery in 1534. Old photographs and descriptions confirm this. Even the past fifty years of rapid change have left its general character unspoilt. A detailed description of the area in 'The Regional Survey of Hatfield Broad Oak' (1928) by Mrs. Annie R. Hatley speaks of the 'red roofs of the town' looking 'particularly attractive across the valley of the Mus Brook.' She notes 'the well-wooded skyline' and writes with enthusiasm about the general panoramic view to be obtained from the church tower as being 'well worth the labour of climbing the stairs'. See Photograph 'A'.
